module.title: Emergency Neurological Life Support
module.comments: This is the first version of ENLS

node.title: Intracerebral Hemorrhage (ICH) Diagnosis
node.explanation:
Intracerebral Hemorrhage (ICH):
ICH typically produces a new headache followed by progressive neurological signs. The onset is usually sudden and many patients progress over a few hours likely due to continuing intracerebral bleeding. It is not possible to be certain whether the stroke is due to hemorrhage or ischemia based on signs and symptoms alone, so some form of brain imaging is necessary. Topic Co-Chairs:
J. Claude Hemphill, MD, MAS
Ed Jauch, MD

Contributors:
Mary Kay Bader, Jon Edlow, Kevin Sheth, Luis Camputaro, Susan Yeager, Oliver Flower

node.title: Heparin
node.explanation: Administer protamine sulfate 1 mg per 100 U heparin received in last 2 hours; maximum dose 50 mg

node.title: Brain Location
node.explanation:
Determine where the bleeding has occurred. Options include:
  • lobar
  • basal ganglia
  • thalamic
  • cerebellar
  • midbrain
  • pons
  • intraventricular blood

node.title: ICH Volume
node.explanation:
If the blood is within the brain parenchyma, use the ABC/2 method.

node.title: Other findings
node.explanation: If IV contrast was administered during the CT scan, extravasation of contrast can be seen in hemorrhages that are still accumulating. This is called the spot sign as shown in the figure: Open image in browser

node.title: Primary Intervention
node.explanation: Intervention for ICH is classified as "primary" meaning what can be done to impact the patient right now, and "secondary" once these primary interventions are addressed. Certainly, one can consider the secondary interventions of blood pressure control, declining neurological exam requiring airway protection, concurrently.

node.title: Coagulopathy
node.explanation: Consider use of vitamin K antagonists, antiplatelet agents, DIC

node.title: Antiplatelet Agents
node.explanation: If the patient has been taking antiplatelet drugs, transfuse with platelets and administer DDAVP 0.3 mcg/kg IV.

node.title: Seizures
node.explanation:
• Do not administer prophylactic anticonvulsants.
  • Treat clinical seizures with benzodiazepines then anticonvulsants.
  • Consider EEG monitoring if the patient's level of consciousness is worse than is likely explained by the size and location of the hemorrhage.

node.title: Blood Pressure
node.explanation: Keep SBP below 160 mm Hg or MAP below 110 mmHg; consider using IV nicardipine with and without IV labetalol

node.title: Surgery
node.body: Is the patient a surgical candidate?
node.explanation:
Cerebellar ICH should be considered for surgery urgently depending on size.
Lobar ICH with mass effect should also be considered for surgery.

node.title: Secondary Treatment
node.explanation: Intervention for ICH is classified as "primary" meaning what can be done to impact the patient right now, and "secondary" once these primary interventions are addressed.

node.title: Control BP
node.explanation: Keep SBP below 160 mm Hg or MAP below 110 mmHg; consider using IV nicardipine with and without IV labetalol

node.title: Airway
node.explanation: ICH may continue to expand and the patient's mental status and airway may become compromised. Continued vigilance to airway is critical especially in posterior fossae hemorrhages.

node.title: ICP Elevated
node.body: Is the patient developing high ICP?
node.explanation: Consider ICP monitoring if GCS <8 or the patient has symptomatic hydrocephalus. See Elevated ICP and Herniation for management recommendations.

node.title: Anticoagulants and DIC
node.explanation:
Consider vitamin K antagonist reversal with purified factor concentrates or FFP if warfarin or other vitamin K antagonists have been prescribed, followed by Vitamin K 10 mg IV.

To calculate the volume of plasma or IU of prothrombin complex concentrate:

1. Decide on target INR

2. Convert INR to percent (%) functional prothrombin complex:

  • > 5 = 5%
  • 4.0 - 4.9 = 10%
  • 2.6 - 3.2 = 15%
  • 2.2 - 2.5 = 20%
  • 1.9 - 2.1 = 25%
  • 1.7 - 1.8 = 30%
  • 1.4 - 1.6 = 40%
  • 1.0 = 100%
    • 3. Calculate dose: (Target in %PC - Current level in %PC) X weight (kg) = mL of FFP or IU of prothrombin-complex concentrate (PCC) needed

    Example: a patient with pulmonary embolism 3 months ago now has warfarin-associated ICH:

    INR on arrival = 7.5, target INR 1.5, body weight = 80 kg;

    (40-5) X 80 = 2,800

    Therefore, the needed dose is 2,800 mL of FFP or 2,800 IU of PCC.
    Reference: Schulman, S. Care of patients receiving long-term anticoagulant therapy. NEJM (2003) 349:675
